newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Korean piano maker defaults, stocks face the music.
newsitem.headline: Korean piano maker defaults, stocks face the music.

text.p: A default by South Korean piano maker Samick Musical Instruments Co Ltd on Thursday unnerved stock investors worried that the music will stop playing for other financially-strapped smaller firms.

On Wednesday the Korea Exchange Bank, Samick's primary lender, said the world's third biggest maker of musical instruments had defaulted on payments on 2.7 billion won ($3.3 million) worth of promissory notes.

Some analysts said it was likely the company would be rescued. But stock investors fretted about the overall health of small companies, many of them suffering from a cash crunch as a result of high interest rates and an export slowdown.
There was some concern about banks with exposure to small firms, the weakest link in South Korea's troubled economy.
Offsetting those fears was news of a two percentage point cut in the bank reserve requirement ratio from November 8 -- a move seen leading to lower interest rates.
Trading in Samick was suspended on Thursday for the second day. It will resume on Friday but the company will be put on a watch list. The shares last traded at 6,140 won.
The leading stock market index ended down 7.54 points at a provisional close of 804.44.
"Small-cap firms could be hurt by the failure news because they always suffer from money supply squeeze," said Choi Kwon-uk, a fund manager at Seoul Investment Trust Co.
Analysts said Samick was likely to apply for court receivership, although a Korea Exchange bank official said no agreement had been reached between Samick and creditors.
Under receivership the company could be restructured with a view to finding a buyer.
"It's most likely that a third party will take over Samick," said Kim Byong-sok, a financial analyst at Hannuri-Salomon Securities.

Samick's total debt stood at 362.5 billion won at the end of June against assets of 372.5 billion. The company posted a net loss of 1.9 billion won in the first half of this year on turnover of 109.6 billion won.
"Samick has a worldwide recognition as a top piano manufacturer. The government wouldn't want to liquidate a company with an international brand name," said Kim.

Analysts said a string of overseas acquisitions in the past several years, plus investments of $18 million in a wood processing plant in Indonesia and $5 million in a piano factory in China, had buried Samick under a mountain of debt.
"Between 1989 and 1991 there was a huge boom of having pianos in middle class households. It was like a status thing," said Chung Jae-yeol, a Ssangyong Securities analyst.
Then consumer tastes changed and "people wanted to have computers in their homes rather than pianos".
Analysts said a weakening Japanese yen also hit Samick's competitiveness against its big rival, Japan's Yamaha Corp.
